This material in this article and in Championing UX Design was a two part talk given at UX Dev Summit 2016. I recommend reading that one first. Because there is so much material in the talk, I wrote these articles for attendees to review and dig in deeper. Even if you weren’t at the talk, I hope you will find it valuable! ¶

In the beginning, there was Waterfall. ¶

And it was…okay. ¶

It’s often conceptualized not by a peaceful waterfall but rather as a series of prison cells.

usersBySocialRecommends.bio: I’m a designer at Findsome & Winmore, UX practioner, marketing graduate, & automobile enthusiast. I’m learning to write and writing to learn.

usersBySocialRecommends.name: Jared M. Spool
usersBySocialRecommends.bio: Thank you for encouraging my behavior! Founder of @UIE. Co-Founder of @CenterCentre. Exploring great user experiences & the wonders of United customer service.

virtuals.emailSnippet:
So, we all make assumptions every day. Our brains fill the blanks in our understanding so that we are able to reach conclusions. Sometimes we consciously arrive at an inference, but often we reach conclusions and take them as fact. If it didn’t, we would become paralyzed by indecision over the simplest of things. ¶

We do this as well when approaching User Experience Design problems. To decide on a design direction we make assumptions about how users will behave or expect a system to work.

virtuals.snippet: I have always said, “UX is a team sport.” This is because often we are our own worst enemies when working in UX by ourselves.
virtuals.subtitle: I have always said, “UX is a team sport.” This is because often we are our own worst enemies when working in UX by ourselves.

usersBySocialRecommends.name: Bohnna Chhim
usersBySocialRecommends.bio: I’m a designer at Findsome & Winmore, UX practioner, marketing graduate, & automobile enthusiast. I’m learning to write and writing to learn.

usersBySocialRecommends.name: Holly Akers
usersBySocialRecommends.bio: Homeschool/Computer Science Teacher FOCUS: Teach Kids in the Year We Live. Learning Web Development to stay one step ahead of my kiddos.

virtuals.emailSnippet:
It is easy for a designer to slip into the trenches of doing without coming up for air. Checking, communicating, examining and challenging the design may fall by the wayside. ¶

We also slip into the opposite mode and get stuck in the clouds — becoming paralyzed by inaction and indecision. In this moment we need to dig in and experiment by doing. ¶

A strong UX team has people on it who can live in both of theses worlds, as both are necessary for any project.

paragraphs.name: 14ac
paragraphs.text: UX is a Team Sport

paragraphs.name: cf4a
paragraphs.text: I have always said, “UX is a team sport.” This is because often we are our own worst enemies when working in UX by ourselves.

virtuals.snippet: What a Problem Statement Looks Like
virtuals.subtitle: What a Problem Statement Looks Like

usersBySocialRecommends.name: Diane Court
usersBySocialRecommends.bio: Voraciously curious, mindmapper & Mom, revisit chaos daily, experiential explorer. Making value connections=work & life. Rule to live by-Benefit others

virtuals.emailSnippet:
Part 2: What a Problem Statement Looks Like ¶

In Part 1, we discussed the value of a problem statement. Now we will dive into the essential components that make a good one. So what does go into a good problem statement? ¶

A problem statement is… ¶

Up first is 1. Laser Focused and 2. To the Point. These first two go together because they feed each other. A problem statement should focus in on a problem.

paragraphs.text: What’s Your Problem? Part 2

virtuals.snippet: The value of a Problem Statement
virtuals.subtitle: The value of a Problem Statement

usersBySocialRecommends.name: Diane Court
usersBySocialRecommends.bio: Voraciously curious, mindmapper & Mom, revisit chaos daily, experiential explorer. Making value connections=work & life. Rule to live by-Benefit others

virtuals.emailSnippet:
Part 1: The value of a Problem Statement ¶

A Problem Statement is an incredible and underutilized tool. It will help your team gain focus, feel a sense of ownership, and reach a successful outcome. But before I continue let me ask you a question: ¶

Are you working on something? Writing code for a feature? Working on the MVP of an app? Working on a marketing campaign? ¶

If so, do you know what problem you are solving with that feature, app, campaign or whatever?

paragraphs.text: What’s Your Problem? Part 1

paragraphs.text: The value of a Problem Statement

value.title: Why do you do what you do?

virtuals.snippet: How your motivations can help you reach success
virtuals.subtitle: How your motivations can help you reach success
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Recently I have been quite focused— you might even say obsessively so—on the why behind the things that I do. I know that most of the things I do have a reason behind them, but unless I take the time to think about them, those reasons can slip into the periphery. ¶

I believe that this can be true for anything in our lives. All of these whys are there, regardless if we think about them or not. ¶

What happens when you lose sight of why you do what you do?

paragraphs.name: title
paragraphs.text: Why do you do what you do?

paragraphs.name: subtitle
paragraphs.text: How your motivations can help you reach success

virtuals.snippet: My Big Takeaways From WebVisions PDX
virtuals.subtitle: My Big Takeaways From WebVisions PDX
virtuals.emailSnippet: Last year I attended WebVisions in Barcelona. This year I spoke at WebVisions in Portland. What I experienced out in Barcelona was inspiring, motivating, and pushed me to submit my proposal to speak this year, and Portland delivered more of the same. Something in the way that this conference brings so many brilliant people from so many diverse backgrounds and varying levels of experience creates a perfect storm of teaching, learning, and cultivating amazing ideas.

virtuals.snippet: Supporting your team, and letting them support you
virtuals.subtitle: Supporting your team, and letting them support you
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Two weeks ago I was in the Smokey Mountains with the 20 or so other members of our development team. We do this work retreat, which we call the Developer Summit, every year. The idea is to gather everybody, get them out of the office, and give them the freedom to think about things that typical day to day needs might keep them from. ¶

During the week we headed out on a team building hike. About midway through an some of my teammates headed off the trail, following their inner child on a quest…
